Description:
Introduction to the pitch and rhythmic aspects of music. Emphasis on aural skills and music notation. Prepares
students for MUS11111, Music Rudiments. No credit toward graduation for music majors or minors.

Prerequisites: Music Theory Placement Test, score of 01.
Description:
Introduction to the pitch and rhythmic aspects of music. Emphasis on aural/oral skills and music notation. No
credit toward graduation for music majors or minors.

Prerequisites: Music Theory Placement Test, score of 02.
Description:
Basic elements of music--harmonic, melodic, rhythmic--studied through analysis, composition, keyboard and
ear training. Diatonic materials emphasized.

Prerequisites: MUS 11121 with a grade ofC (2.00) or better.
Description:
Continuation of basic elements of music--harmonic, melodic, rhythmic-- studied through analysis, composition,
keyboard, singing and ear training. Chromatic materials emphasized.

Development of basic skills required in playing piano, including familiarity with the keyboard and music
notation.

Development of basic skills required in playing piano, including familiarity with the keyboard and music
notation.

Preparatory piano. Credit not acceptable on music major sequences. Piano literature and functional elements
of sight-reading, transposition, harmonization and improvisation.

Prerequisites: MUS 17111 with a grade of C(2.000) or better.
Description:
Preparatory piano. Credit not acceptable on music major sequences. Piano literature and functional elements
of sight-reading, transposition, harmonization and improvisation.

Foundational training and performance practice in phonetics and singing diction for the English, American,
Ecclesiastical Latin and Italian vocal repertoire.

Prerequisites: Music (MUS) major and MUS 18611 with a gradeof C (2.000) or better.
Description:
Foundational training and performance practice in phonetics and singing diction for the vocal repertoire of
French, German and selected other languages.

(Repeatable for credit)Academic study in areas not offered adequately in the music curriculum. Topic areas are
of special interest to the faculty member.

A practical introduction to digital audio production, study of basic computer assisted recording, editing and
music production.

Prerequisites: MUS 21113 and 21221 with minimum C (2.000) grade.
Description:
A practical study of computer assisted composition and arranging covering MIDI, sequencing, synthesis,
sampling and video synchronization.

Prerequisites: MUS 11122 with a grade of C (2.000) or better.
Description:
Study of Western musical style from Gregorian chant through the Baroque period. Emphasis on aural,
compositional, written and keyboard approaches as appropriate to medieval, Renaissance and Baroque music.

Prerequisites: MUS 21121with a grade of C (2.000) or better.
Description:
Study of Western musical style from the early classical to the late Romantic period. Emphasis on aural,
compositional, written and keyboard approaches as appropriate to classical and Romantic music.

Prerequisites: minimum grade of C (2.000) in MUS 21113.
Description:
A study of basic live and studio recording fundamentals and techniques, including signal flow, microphones
and recording equipment.

A study of multi-track miking and recording techniques, session setup and management, and elements
required for the reference mix.

Prerequisites: Minimum grade of C (2.000) in MUS 11121 and 11122.
Description:
Application of the knowledge gained from Music Theory (MUS 11121 and 11122) to the study of popular
music through practical applications, particularly with regard to composition and improvisation.

A listening approach for the understanding of Western art music, folk and jazz. Particular attention is paid to
musical styles forms and compositional techniques as related to music history.

An introduction to music as a world phenomenon. Study of selected art, folk and popular musics from world
cultures through live performances, tapes, films, video tapes and readings.

A survey of Rock Music History from the 1950s through the twentieth century to today. Emphasis is on
recognizing music literature, prominent artists and music styles, as well as related cultural events. Modern
media, especially the Internet, is an integral component of the course.

Basic teaching strategies and techniques; an overview of music teaching as a career; diversity, integration,
curriculum technology, classroom management, legal issues, personal skills and portfolio. Twenty (20) field
hours required.

(Repeatable for credit) Choral ensemble which studies and performs sacred and secular music for mixed
voices. Activities include performance on and off campus.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music literature for wind band appropriate for music majors
and non-majors.
(Repeatable for credit) The study and performance of music for small ensembles.

The World Music Ensemble teaches performance and cultural etiquette associated with traditional and popular
world music genres, e.g., African drumming. Specific traditions studied include areas of specialization of
instructors andor advanced student participants.

Prerequisites: MUS17112 with a grade of C (2.000) or better.
Description: Continuation of piano classes. Credit acceptable on music major and minor sequences.

Prerequisites: MUS27111with a minimum grade of C (2.000).
Description: Continuation of piano classes. Credit acceptable on music major and minor sequences.

Advanced sight singing and ear training. Sight singing in five clefs emphasizing vocal and instrumental works
from various periods including contemporary.

Prerequisites: Minimum grade of C (2.000) in 21114; and musictechnology (MUST) major.
Description:
Continuation of Music Production II. Advanced sequencing, synthesis and audio editing techniques as applied
to music production. Focus is on arranging.

Prerequisites: Minimum grade ofC (2.000) in MUS 31113; and music technology (MUST) major.
Description:
Continuation of Music Production III. Arranging for acoustic and electronic instruments as applied to music
production. Development of MIDI programming skills and use of sample sets.

Prerequisites: MUS 21122 and MUS 32212, both with C (2.000) minimum grade.
Description:
Class meets three hours per week. The study of western art music since 1900 from historical and theoretical
viewpoints. Emphasis on aural listening music composition and written skills as well as intellectual
understanding.

(Repeated for credit) original composition for instrumental and vocal solos and small ensembles using shorter
musical forms.

Prerequisites: Minimumgrade of C (2.000) in MUS 21222; and music technology (MUST) major.
Description: A study of the elements, functions and techniques of digital audio multi-track mixing.

Prerequisites: Minimum grade of C (2.000) in MUS 31221; and music technology (MUST)major.
Description:
A detailed study of the tools, techniques and critical listening decisions required in creating a professional
digital audio mix.

Prerequisites: MUS22111 (music major section) with a grade of C (2.000) or better; and junior standing.
Description: A survey of Western music history from early Christian chants through the Baroque style.

Prerequisites: MUS 22111 (music majorsection); and MUS 32211 with a grade of C (2.000) or better and junior standing.
Description: A survey of Western music history of the 18th and 19th centuries.

Prerequisites: grade of C (2.000) orbetter in MUS 23241; and music (MUS) or music education (MUED) major; and junior standing.
Description:
Kodaly, Orff, Dalcroze and current strategies appropriate for early childhood K-12 general music classrooms.
Emphasis on teaching diverse learners, including special student populations. Clinical experience in the
teaching of general music in the schools. Forty (40) field hours required.
Clinical experience in the teaching of general and instrumental music. Fifteen field hours required.

Prerequisites: MUS 33212; and music (MUS) or music education (MUED) major; and junior standing.
Description: Clinical experience in the teaching of choral and instrumental music. Fifteen field hours required.

The application of technologies specific to music instruction and learning for music education majors. Emphasis
is placed on project-based instruction focusing on the practical uses of technology in school settings.

Prerequisites: grade of C (2.000)or better in MUS 23241 and 34111; and junior standing.
Description:
Methods, materials, and literature used in elementary and secondary choral music programs; designing a
choral curriculum, advocacy and assessment, lesson planning, program organization, budget. Clinical
experience in the teaching of choral music. Forty (40) field hours required.

Prerequisites: MUS 21121with a minimum grade of C(2.000).
Description:
Introduction to and study of conducting: beat patterns, baton techniques, score reading, analysis and
interpretive elements. Six field/clinical hours are required.

(Repeatable for a maximium of 16 credit hours) Development of ensemble skills through small group
experience performing diverse popular styles from notation, developing improvisation skills and creating
arrangements from lead charts. Students must audition for the director prior to registration for the course.
(Repeatable for credit)Private instrumental instruction in Jazz techniques.

Prerequisites: Music (MUS), music technology (MUST) or music education (MUED) major.2.000 OR
Description:
(Repeatable for credit) A comprehensive study of performance, technique and repertoire appropriate to music
majors and minors. Individual study. Students must audition to be accepted into this course.

(Repeatable for a maximum of 16 credit hours) Development of performance proficiency in contemporary
popular music styles appropriate for the performance idiom through individual instruction. Students must
audition for the director prior to registration for the course.
Development of keyboard facility for practical purposes in classroom.

Course Name: PIANO SKILLS FOR THE CHORAL/GENERAL MUSIC EDUCATOR
Prerequisites: MUS 21122 and 36111 with a minimum grade of C (2.000).
Description: Development of keyboard skills for practical purposes in the classroom and ensemble rehearsals.

Course Name: PIANO SKILLS FOR THE INSTRUMENTAL MUSIC EDUCATOR
Prerequisites: MUS 17112 and 21122 with a minimum grade of C (2.000) in both courses; or minimum scoreof 80 on piano placement test.
Description: Development of keyboard skills for practical purposes in the classroom and ensemble rehearsals.

Prerequisites:
Minimum grade of C(2.000) in MUS 31114 or 31222; and a cumulative 2.250 GPA; and music technology (MUST) major and
special approval.
Description:
(Repeatable for a maximum of 4 credit hours) On-the-job experience with cooperating business in the field of
music technology and preparation of a final report or an applicable project.

(repeatable for a total of 12 hours) Academic study in areas not offered adequately in the music curriculum.
Topic areas are of special interest to the faculty member.

Prerequisites: Music (MUS) or music education (MUED)major and special approval.
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)Individual investigation in music topics not offered as either regular coursework or
beyond the scope of existing music major courses.
Ear training,sight singing and analysis in preparation for graduate level music theory course work.

Prerequisites: Minimum grade of C (2.000) in MUS 31114; andmusic technology (MUST) major.
Description:
Continuation of Music Production IV, advanced sequencing, synthesis and audio editing techniques as applied
to music production. Focus is on original music.

Prerequisites: Minimum grade of C (2.000) in MUS 41113.
Description:
Continuation of Music Production V, create music to accompany a visual medium by learning fundamental to
more advanced film scoring techniques.

Prerequisites: MUS 21122 with a minimum grade ofC (2.000).
Description:
Theoretical skills demonstrated at the keyboard: harmonization of melodies in homophonic style, realization of
figured bass, score reading, modulation and improvisation.

Prerequisites: MUS 21122 with a minimumgrade of C (2.000).
Description: Two-, three -and four part vocal counterpoint in 16th century style.

Prerequisites: MUS 21122with a minimum grade of C (2.000).
Description: Technique of writing counterpoint in 18th-century style, especially that of J. S. Bach.

Prerequisites: MUS 31121 with a minimum grade ofC (2.000).
Description:
A study of 20th-century approaches to tonal and nontonal musical analysis. Emphasis on familiarity with
styles, nomenclature and appropriate graphic techniques.

An introduction to acoustics and psychoacoustics in direct relationship to music, and an introduction to uses of
technology in music composition, performance, notation, theory, history and pedagogy.
(Repeatable for credit)Preparation and presentation of a senior thesis in the student's area of expertise.

Prerequisites:
Composition (COMP) or music (MUS) or musiceducation (MUED) major. 
2.000 OR
Description:
Study of the materials and techniques of musical composition culminating in original works based upon
observable principles of unity and variety.

Prerequisites: Minimum grade of C (2.000) in MUS31222; and music technology (MUST) major.
Description:
A detailed study in digital audio production techniques and procedures, including project management, final
product editing and assembly, and digital audio mastering.

Prerequisites: minimum grade of C(2.000) in MUS 41221.
Description:
A comprehensive project experience in digital audio from pre-production through the recording, mixing,
mastering, assembly and post-production of a complete audio project.

Prerequisites: MUS 41211 with a minimum grade of C (2.000).
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)The final composition experience prior to graduation: a recital of individually composed
works must be presented.

Prerequisites: MUS 21122 with aminimum grade of C (2.000).
Description:
Ranges, tonal possibilities, technical limitations and transpositions for all orchestral instruments. Scoring
techniques and analysis of representative instrumental ensemble repertoire.

(Repeatable for a total of 4 credit hours) A beginner's introduction to Jazz improvisation. Theory and daily
playing will be enhanced by ear training.

(Repeatable for a maximum of 4 credit hours) Composing and arranging for the large and small jazz
ensemble.

Prerequisites: MUS 41341 witha minimum grade of C (2.000) or special approval via audition.
Description: The presentation of a methodical approach to learning standard Jazz repertoire.

Roots of Rock is a comprehensive survey of the various genres of American music in the 20th century that
contributed to the development of rock music. Important performers in various styles and their contributions
to the art form are explored. Pioneers in the fields of recording, artist management and production are
studied. Rock musicâ€™s contributions to the emergence of American culture are viewed in the context of social,
racial and political changes. The impact of technological advances in radio, recording and television are also
studied.

African music as related to social sciences and humanities. Oral traditions. Use of music recordings, tapes,
musical instruments, participation in performance and group work involvement.
Historical survey of music in America from new England psalmody to present-day compositional trends.

Course Name: FOLK AND TRADITIONAL MUSIC OF WESTERN CONTINENTS
Description: Study of selected music cultures of Eastern and Western Europe, and South, Central and North America.

Survey of Asian musics. Emphasis on art, folk and popular musics and relationships of these musics to their
respective cultures.
The evolution of jazz from its origin to present.

A survey of popular world music genres from North America, the Caribbean, South America, Europe, Africa
and Asia. Emphasis is on recognizing music literature, prominent artists and music styles, as well as related
cultural events. Modern media, especially the Internet, is an integral component of the course.

Prerequisites: MUS 21122 with aminimum grade of C (2.000).
Description: Historical and stylistic survey of music for large instrumental ensemble.

Survey of keyboard and piano literature from the 16th century to the present ;study of related forms and
styles. Emphasis on performing listening and analysis.

Prerequisites: MUS 22111 minimum grade of C(2.000) grade; and junior standing.
Description:
A study of vocal literature from the 16th century to the present. Emphasis upon the style, interpretation and
presentation of solo materials for all voice classifications.

Prerequisites: MUS 22111 with a minimum C (2.000) grade; and junior standing.
Description:
The historical development of opera from the 17th century to the present. Detailed analysis of representative
works.

Prerequisites: MUS 31121with a minimum grade of C (2.000) andspecial approval of instructor.
Description:
Study of Western European choral literature from approximately 1450 to the early nineteenth century, i.e.,
Renaissance, Baroque and Classical periods.

Prerequisites: MUS31121 with a minimum grade of C (2.000); and special approval from the instructor.
Description:
Choral Literature II, a continuation of Choral Literature I, is a study of Western European and North American
choral music of the early nineteenth century to the present (roughly 1830 to the present).

Prerequisites:
Music education (MUED) majorand special approval; and Official valid certification of Child Safety Training, approved Basic Life Support and
A.L.I.C.E. Training must be presented to the campus office of clinical experience or designated faculty/staff at
Regional campuses as prerequisite for student teaching.
Description:
Provides a 16-week student teaching experience. Off-campus arrangements are handled by the College of
Education, Health and Human Services and the School of Music.

Prerequisites: grade of C (2.000) or better in MUS 23241 and 34111 and 43231; and 3 credits witha C (2.000) or better in MUS 47411 or 47511 or 47611 or 47711; and junior standing.
Description:
Secondary instrumental instruction; program organization, budget, advocacy, assessment, rehearsal planning,
literature and teaching techniques. Clinical experience in the teaching of music. Forty (40) field hours
required.

Prerequisites:
grade of C (2.000) or betterin MUS 23241; and 2 credits with a C or better in MUS 47411 or 47511 or 47611 or 47711; music (MUS) or
music education (MUED) major; and junior standing.
Description:
Elementary and middle school instrumental instruction, program organization, rehearsal teaching techniques,
lesson plans, literature, assessment, scheduling, recruiting, modeling and interactive teaching. Clinical
experience in the teaching of music. Forty (40) field hours required.

Prerequisites: music education (MUED) major and sophomore standing.
Description:
anization, administration and techniques of marching bands in the schools. Topics covered include musical
styles, literature and show design.

Study of the curriculum for the jazz ensemble,including organizational and administrative procedures.
Emphasis on music interpretation jazz styles and rehearsal techniques taught through laboratory experience.

Course Name: VOCAL JAZZ AND MUSICAL THEATRE IN THE SCHOOLS
Description:
History, vocal technique, style characteristics and repertoire necessary for teaching vocal jazz and African-
American spirituals. Repertoire organization and publicity for school productions of American musical theatre.

Continued development of conducting technique, score reading analysis, styles, interpretation, rehearsal
procedure, language pronunciation and arranging for voices and instruments. Six field/ clinical hours are
required.

Prerequisites: MUS 34111 with a minimum grade of C (2.000).
Description:
Continued development of conducting technique, score reading analysis, styles, interpretation, rehearsal
procedure and arranging for instrumental organizations. Twelve field/clinical hours are required.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of choral music from Renaissance through contemporary styles,
large and small forms with appropriate accompaniment.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of choral music from Renaissance through contemporary styles,
large and small forms with appropriate accompaniment.

(Repeatable for credit) Training in methods and skills necessary to the art of the singer-actor. Opera
performed and prepared via study observation and rehearsal.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of literature for vocal chamber ensemble from medieval
through contemporary styles with appropriate accompaniment sung in the original language. An audition is
required before registering for this course.

(Repeatable for credit) A chorus of male voices. Emphasis on music literacy, vocal production instruction study
and performance of music written for male voices. All western music periods are represented. Experience with
mixed voice choirs also occurs.

(Repeatable for credit) A chorus of women's voices. Emphasis on music literacy, vocal production instruction
study and performance of music written for women's voices. All western music periods are represented.
Experience with mixed voice choirs also occurs.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of choral music in the gospel tradition, including works by
contemporary artists. One weekly rehearsal and a minimum of one concert per semester. Off-campus concerts
are possible.

(Repeatable for credit) A select group of instrumentalists for the purpose of studying and performing music
written specifically for chamber orchestra including works of the 17th,18th and 20th centuries. An audition is
required before registering for this course.
(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music literature for wind band.
(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of literature and maneuvers for marching band.

(Repeatable for credit) A select concert ensemble that performs the finest in wind instrument literature with
emphasis on major original works. An audition is required before registering for this course.
(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music for the basketball band.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music literature for wind band appropriate for non-music
majors, and for music education majors performing on secondary instruments.
(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music literature in the jazz idiom.

(Repeatable for credit) A thorough study of trombone performance in various sized ensembles. Emphasis on
original literature from over four centuries.

(Repeatable for credit) A comprehensive study of percussion performance in various-sized ensembles. Use of
keyboard percussion instruments along with drums and accessories. Study of percussion ensemble literature.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music for multiple bassoons;emphasis upon refined
ensemble playing interpretation leadership skills and arranging techniques.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of 20th-century chamber music with an emphasis on works by
contemporary composers.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music for multiple flutes;emphasis upon all aspects of
ensemble playing and style considerations will be addressed in both chamber and conducted formats.
(Repeatable for credit) The study and performance of music for small ensembles.
(Repeatable for a total of 8 credit hours) The study of Jazz combo performance through rehearsal.

(Repeatable for credit) Accompanying instrumental and vocal soloists;piano ensemble works. Credit counted
toward ensemble requirements. One hour credit for two hours of assigned accompanying weekly.

Development of basic folk guitar performance skills.

Continued development of acoustic guitar performance skills, study of performance related theory and related
topics such as open tuning and slide guitar.

Course Name: FOLK GUITAR FOR THE MUSIC EDUCATOR
Description: Development of basic folk guitar performance skills for music education majors.
Class instruction in the fundamentals of correct breathing, tone production and diction.

Class lessons in basic playing skills, methodology, teaching materials and maintenance of string instruments to
enable the student to teach string classes in public schools.

Study of fundamental principles of performance on woodwind instruments; methods and materials for class
and private instruction.

Study of fundamental principles of playing and teaching brass instruments. Survey of materials and method
books suitable for class and private instruction.

Study of various percussion instruments (mallets, snare drum, timpani and auxiliary) and techniques of
performance. Designed for music educator with no previous percussion experience.

Course Name: INSTRUMENT CLASS FOR THE CHORAL/GENERAL MUSIC EDUCATOR
Description:
Class instruction in the basic playing skills of band and orchestral instruments intended to provide familiarity
with the common school instruments for the choral/general music major.

Prerequisites: Music (MUS) or musiceducation (MUED) and junior standing.
Description:
Observation and teaching of individual and class lessons, children and adults. Study and performance of
preparatory materials, elementary through intermediate piano literature.

Techniques of accompanying; selected overview of art song literature including Italian, German, French and
English songs development of playing at sight skills.

Prerequisites: MUS48221 with a minimum grade of C (2.000).
Description:
Continuation of accompanying techniques including opera accompanying, orchestral reductions and selected
overview of literature for solo instrument and piano; continuation of playing-at-sight skills.
Survey of techniques,practices and materials of teaching voice.

Prerequisites: MUS 21122 with a minimum grade of C(2.000).
Description: The principles and techniques of teaching music theory.

Principles and techniques of instruction. Literature survey. Analysis of instrumental problems and performance
practice. Offered as needed for strings woodwinds brass percussion organ,or guitar.

(Repeatable for credit)Offered for specific professional needs. Emphasis on performance and pedagogical skills.
S/U graded.

Prerequisites: MUS 21121 with a minimum grade of C (2.000).
Description:
The development of musical improvisation skills not tied to any particular music style. Students will perform
on their own applied instrument(s).
(repeated registration permitted) research or individual investigation for undergraduate students.

A capstone discussion of principles of music teaching and pragmatic understanding of school music settings.
Seminar serves as the companion course to Student Teaching for the purpose of self-observation, reflection,
and analysis. Development of Teacher Work Sample and portfolio.

(Repeatable for credit)Academic study in areas not offered adequately in the music curriculum. Topic areas are
of special interest to the faculty member.

Prerequisites: Graduate standing and music (MUS) majorand special approval.
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)Individual investigation in music topics not offered as either regular coursework or
beyond the scope of existing music major courses.

Theoretical skills demonstrated at the keyboard. Harmonization of melodies in homophonic style, realization of
figured bass, score reading, modulation and improvisation.
Two-, three- and four-part vocal counterpoint in 16th century style.
Technique of writing counterpoint in 18th-century style especially that of J. S. Bach.

A study of 20th-century approaches to tonal and nontonal musical analysis. Emphasis on familiarity with
styles, nomenclature and appropriate graphic techniques.

(Repeatable for credit) Study of the materials and techniques of composition culminating in original
compositions based upon observable principles of unity and variety.

Ranges, tonal possibilities, technical limitations and transpositions for all orchestral instruments. Scoring
techniques and analysis of representative instrumental ensemble repertoire.
The development of the art of jazz improvisation through performance and analysis.
Arranging for the large and small jazz ensemble.

African music as related to social sciences and humanities. Oral traditions. Use of music recordings, tapes,
musical instruments. Participation in performance and group work involvement.
Historical survey of music in America from New England psalmody to present-day compositional trends.

Course Name: FOLK AND TRADITIONAL MUSIC OF WESTERN CONTINENTS
Description: Study of selected music cultures of Eastern and Western Europe, and South, Central and North America.

Survey of Asian musics. Emphasis on art, folk and popular musics and relationships of these musics to their
respective cultures.
The evolution of jazz from its origins to the present.

Study of selected art, folk and popular music from world cultures with emphasis on listening skills, cultural
context, function, organology and technical matters of style.

A survey of popular world music genres from North America, the Caribbean, South America, Europe, Africa,
and Asia. Emphasis is on recognizing music literature, prominent artists and music styles, as well as related
cultural events. Graduate level introduces cultural theory related to popular studies. Modern media, especially
the Internet, is an integral component of the course.
Historical and stylistic survey of music for large instrumental ensemble.

Survey of keyboard and piano literature from the 16th century to the present. Study of related forms and
styles. Emphasis on performing listening and analysis.

A study of vocal literature from the 16th century to the present. Emphasis upon the style, interpretation and
presentation of solo materials for all voice classifications.

The historical development of opera from the 17th century to the present. Detailed analysis of representative
works.

Study of Western European choral literature from approximately 1450 to early nineteenth century, i.e.,
Renaissance, Baroque, and Classical periods.

Choral Literature II, a continuation of Choral Literature I, is a study of Western European and North American
choral music of the early nineteenth century to the present (roughly 1830 to present).

Organization, administration and techniques of marching bands in the schools. Topics covered include musical
styles, literature and show design.

Study of the curriculum for the jazz ensemble, including organizational and administrative procedures.
Emphasis on music interpretation, jazz styles and rehearsal techniques taught through laboratory experience.

Course Name: VOCAL JAZZ AND MUSICAL THEATRE IN THE SCHOOLS
Description:
Basic techniques and materials for teaching vocal jazz and musical theatre in the schools. Administration,
organization and publicity for productions as well as literature for these performing groups will be explored.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of choral music from Renaissance through contemporary styles,
large and small forms with appropriate accompaniment.

(Repeatable for credit) A course designed to give the young singing actor practical operatic experience in the
performance of portions of or complete operas.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of literature for vocal chamber ensemble from medieval
through contemporary styles sung in the original language with appropriate accompaniment. An audition in
required before registering for this course.

(Repeatable for credit) A chorus of male voices. Emphasis on music literacy, vocal production, instruction,
study and performance of music written for male voices. All western music periods are represented.
Experience with mixed-voice choirs also occurs.

(Repeatable for credit) A chorus of women's voices. Emphasis on music literacy, vocal production, instruction,
study and performance of music written for women's voices. All Western music periods are represented.
Experience with mixed-voice choirs also occurs.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of choral music in the gospel tradition, including works by
contemporary artists. One weekly rehearsal and a minimum of one concert per semester. Off-campus concerts
are possible.

(Repeatable for credit) A select group of instrumentalists for the purpose of studying and performing music
written specifically for chamber orchestra including works of the 17th, 18th and 20th centuries. An audition in
required before registering for this course.
(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music literature for wind band.

(Repeatable for a maximum of 6 credit hours) Study and performance of literature and maneuvers for
marching band.

(Repeatable for credit) A select concert ensemble that performs the finest in wind instrument literature with
emphasis on major original works. An audition in required before registering for this course.
(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music literature in the jazz idiom.

(Repeatable for credit) A thorough study of trombone performance in various size ensembles. Emphasis on
original literature from over four centuries.

(Repeatable for credit) A comprehensive study of percussion performance in various size ensembles. Use of
keyboard percussion instruments along with drums and accessories. Study of percussion ensemble literature.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music for multiple bassoons; emphasis upon refined
ensemble playing, interpretation, leadership skills and arranging techniques.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of 20th-century chamber music with an emphasis on works by
contemporary composers.

(Repeatable for credit) Study and performance of music for multiple flutes; emphasis upon all aspects of
ensemble playing and style considerations will be addressed in both chamber and conducted formats.
(Repeatable for credit) The study and performance of music for small ensembles.

(Course is repeatable for a maximum of 8 credit hours) The World Music Ensemble teaches performance and
cultural etiquette associated with traditional and popular world music genres, e.g., African drumming. Specific
traditions studied include areas of specialization of instructors andor advanced student participants.

(Repeatable for credit) Accompanying instrumental and vocal soloists; piano ensemble works. Credit counted
toward ensemble requirements. One hour credit for two hours of assigned accompanying weekly.

Techniques of accompanying; selected overview of art song literature including Italian, German, French and
English songs development of playing at sight skills.
Survey of techniques, practices and materials of teaching voice.
The principles and techniques of teaching music theory.

Principles and techniques of instruction. Literature survey. Analysis of instrumental problems and performance
practice. Offered as needed for strings, woodwinds, brass, percussion, organ or guitar.
(Repeatable for credit)Offered for specific professional needs. Emphasis on performance and pedagogical skills.

(Cross-listed with MUS 71121) A study of the history of Western music theory from the ancient Greeks to the
twentieth century.

An introduction to musical analysis according to the principles expounded by Heinrich Schenker and later
exponents of his ideas.

Selected analytical techniques applied to music from the tonal and post-tonal repertoire. Emphasis on the
development of harmonic language and overall formal structures.
The application of standard analytical techniques to works of various style periods.
The application of standard analytical techniques to works of various style periods.

Analysis of world music traditions. Analyze and articulate knowledge regarding musical elements, such as
timbre, tuning, improvisation, sound patterns, compositional form, and performance techniques of music
genres studied. Development of listening and transcription skills as they relate to world music.
A study of the analysis, theories, and compositional strategies applied to the music composed after 1900.

(Cross-listed with MUS 71191) (Course is repeatble for a maximum of 6 creidt hours) Study of analytical
techniques and procedures appropriate for the major musical styles of the period. Study of representative
compositions through applied analysis. Individual projects in areas of particular interest to the student.

(Repeatable for credit) Original composition using longer forms of music for diverse media including
multimedia and electronic composition.
Arranging in traditional and contemporary styles for the wind ensemble, concert band and/or marching band.

Course Name: SEMINAR IN MUSIC HISTORY AND LITERATURE
Description:
(Repeatable for credit) Selected problems of research in music history and literature. Each student will be
responsible for presenting papers for discussion.

Study of techniques of music research and creative musical writing including special projects, reports and
readings. This course is a hybrid course consisting of both in-class meetings and discussions, as well as online
interaction and discussion boards.

Prerequisites: MUS 52111 or MUS 52141 or MUS 52151 and graduate standing.
Description:
A study of the history, concepts and methods of ethnomusicology, techniques of field research, transcription,
analysis and bibliography.

Course Name: ADVANCED FIELD AND LAB METHODS IN ETHNOMUSICOLOGY
Description:
Development of professional level research skills in all media of field documentation, transcription, analysis
and scholarly writing. Study of current related issues in ethnomusicology.

This course studies various issues and trends in the field of ethnomusicology, from its inception to present.
The focus centers on intensive discussion of theories, philosophies and paradigms that have dominated the
scrutiny of music over the decades and their application in analysis, fieldwork and lab method.
Techniques of music research and creative musical writing including special projects, reports and readings.

A study of Western music history from Jewish and medieval Roman practices through Josquin, as well as
selected common-practice period applications.
A study of Western music history from the Reformation and Counter-Reformatiion through Bach and Handel.
A study of Western music history in the Rococo, Classical, and Romantic periods through Brahms and Wagner.

A study of Western music from Debussy and Mahler through the major trends and composers of the recent
past.
Specialized investigations of music cultures of Africa.

Course Name: SEMINAR IN MUSICS OF THE AMERICAS
Description: Specialized investigation of music cultures of the Americas.

Course Name: SEMINAR IN MUSICS OF THE MIDDLE EAST
Description: Specialized investigation of music cultures of the Middle East.

Course Name: SEMINAR IN MUSICS OF EAST ASIA
Description: Specialized investigation of music cultures of East Asia.

Course Name: SEMINAR IN MUSICS OF SOUTHEAST ASIA
Description: Specialized investigation of music cultures in Southeast Asia.

(Repeatable for credit)Working under the supervision of a capstone advisor, students demonstrate synthesis of
knowledge through the development of curricular project applicable to student's area of teaching.

Conducting and presenting assessment, evaluation, and research of music teaching and learning with
emphasis on quantitative methodologies.

Course Name: INQUIRY IN MUSIC TEACHING AND LEARNING II
Description:
Conducting and presenting assessment, evaluation and research of music teaching and learning with emphasis
on qualitative methodologies.

Course Name: ADVANCED STUDIES IN TEACHING CHORAL MUSIC
Description:
Development of teaching materials, an annotated choral repertory list and instructional strategies for choral
music with emphasis on rehearsal procedures and analytical techniques.

Course Name: ADVANCED STUDIES IN TEACHING INSTRUMENTAL MUSIC
Description:
Development of teaching materials, an annotated instrumental repertory list and instructional strategies for
instrumental music with emphasis on rehearsal procedures and analytical techniques.

Course Name: ADVANCED STUDIES IN TEACHING GENERAL MUSIC
Description:
Program development, inclusion, instructional materials and innovative teaching techniques for general music
programs.
Application of current theories of learning to the teaching and learning of music.

The study of music's effect on human behavior including physiological and affective responses. Applications of
music psychology to the teaching and learning of music will be explored.

Study of the field of music education from perspectives of sociology, psychology, philosophy, curriculum,
history and comparative curricula.

Introduction to research techniques in music education including topic selection, data collection analysis and
interpretation, and presentation of information in written form.

Study of historical approaches to music education with emphasis on significant people, places and events that
have influenced music teaching and learning music.

Study of the philosophical foundations of music education with emphasis on the application of aesthetics to
teaching and experiencing music.

Sociology in Music Education focuses on sociocultural issues in music teaching and learning. Students consider
contexts of society, background, race, ethnicity, culture, diversity, and pluralism as applicable in music
education situations.

Choral conducting techniques, score analysis, rehearsal procedures and study of musical style. Repeatable
credit.
Band conducting techniques,score analysis rehearsal procedures and study of musical style. Repeatable credit.

Orchestra conducting techniques, score analysis, rehearsal procedures and study of musical style. Repeatable
credit.

Prerequisites: Music major and graduate standing.2.000 OR
Description:
(Repeatable for credit) A comprehensive study of performance, technique and repertoire appropriate to music
majors and minors. Individual study. Students must audition to be accepted into this course.

(Repeatable for credit)Studio performances of standard repertoire for piano and voice or instruments;
investigation of other topics relating to the accompanying of the repertoire.

Prerequisites: Music major and special approval. Graduate standing.2.000 OR
Description:
(Repeatable for credit) A comprehensive study of performance, technique and repertoire appropriate to music
majors and minors. Individual study. Students must audition to be accepted into this course.

Description:

Study of a variety of music software and hardware; students design and implement a project pertaining to
their professional interest.

Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several
semesters if desired.

Teaching techniques and materials for the studio teacher including approach to philosophy of teaching, lesson
structure and current innovations.

Teaching techniques and materials for the studio teacher; analysis of specific teaching problems including the
teaching of 20th century music.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.
(Repeatable for credit)Research or individual investigation for master's level graduate students.
Required of all performance majors and music education majors who choose performance option.

(Repeatable for credit)Required of performance majors and music education majors who choose the recital
and essay option.

Individual and class investigation into specific methods of analysis and their application to music in various
styles.
Arranging in traditional and contemporary styles for the wind ensemble, concert band and/or marching band.

Description:

(Repeatable for credit)Specialized topics in ethnomusicology for advanced students.

Course Name: ADVANCED STUDIES IN SECONDARY CHORAL AND GENERAL MUSIC
Description:
Review curriculum in secondary general music and development of innovative teaching materials and
strategies. Analytical techniques, rehearsal procedures, repertory suitable for secondary school choral
ensembles.
Study of curriculum, method techniques and materials in school instrumental music education.

Course Name: ADVANCED STUDIES IN GENERAL MUSIC FOR CHILDREN
Description:
Study of trends in philosophy, curriculum and program development, instructional materials and innovative
teaching techniques for elementary school and early childhood general music.
Application of current theories of learning to the teaching and learning of music.

The study of music's effect on human behavior including physiological and affective responses. Applications of
music psychology to the teaching and learning of music will be explored.

Study of the influences on the field of music education, including sociology, psychology, philosophy,
curriculum and history.

Introduction to research techniques in music education including topic selection, data collection analysis and
interpretation and presentation of information in written form.

Study of historical approaches to music education with emphasis on significant people, places and events that
have influenced teaching and learning music.

Study of the philosophical foundations of music education with emphasis on the application of aesthetics to
teaching and experiencing music.

Sociology in Music Education focuses on sociocultural issues in music teaching and learning. Students consider
contexts of society, background, race, ethnicity, culture, diversity and pluralism as applicable in music
education situations.

(Repeatable for credit)Advanced study in selected topics that will vary from semester to semester depending
on needs and interests of students.

The design, implementation and reporting of research studies that illustrate a variety of methodological and
statistical plans for research in music education.

Choral conducting techniques, score analysis, rehearsal procedures and study of musical style. Repeatable
credit.

Course Name: SEMINAR IN TEACHER EDUCATION IN MUSIC
Description:
Investigation of the role of curriculum, accreditation and certification in music teacher education. Procedures
related to teaching methods courses and to the student teaching program.

This courses prepares students for doctoral study in music education. Topics include understanding tasks and
skills necessary for PhD study in music education, along with navigating this study at Kent State. Students
interact in seminar format as part of a cohort of students pursuing the study of music teaching and learning.

Prerequisites: MUS 86001, CI 87000 and EVAL 75510; doctoral standing.
Description:
This doctoral level course is designed to ready students for final activities of PhD study in music education.
Goals include preparation for qualifying exams, understanding of the research proposal process, and
exploration of advanced research methodologies and protocols necessary to undertake a dissertation and or
significant research project.

Prerequisites: Pass candidacy examination and doctoral standing.
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)Doctoral dissertation for which registration in at least two semesters is required, first of
which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.

(Repeatable for credit)Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30
hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.

(Repeatable for credit)Research or individual investigation for doctoral students who have not yet passed their
candidacy examinations.
